name: 2025 - Dragon Ride 6/22/25
description:
Get ready to conquer the Dragon Ride event on June 22nd with our comprehensive 6-week training plan, designed to elevate your performance to new heights. This specialized program not only focuses on optimizing your cycling strength and endurance but also integrates yoga sessions to ensure you're physically prepared for the challenge ahead.

​

Our training plan is designed by our extremely knowledgable sports science team and is tailored to help you tackle the diverse terrain of the event, combining intense cycling workouts with rejuvenating yoga sessions to enhance flexibility and recovery.

​

If you are in need of any technical help or want to know more about the training terms used in this plan check out the [Wahoo SYSTM Help Center.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenter)

​

Have a more specific question that isn't addressed in the Help Center? Head over to our [forum](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/) to see if your question has been answered, or just post it for yourself.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: N. Henderson 2: Rabbit Mountain
prospects.description:
It's your first day joining Neal for a ride, so he's taking you out with a few of his friends -- Jeff, Julie, and Heather -- for a series of four, 10-minute repeats on the infamous Rabbit Mountain. And while the road might repeat, the efforts won't as Neal's come up with a different approach for each one.

​

In between the efforts, you'll learn that Neal is a bit of a collector -- at least when it comes to cycling stuff. He shows you his personal bike collection (he really takes N+1 to the next level), lets you dig around in his wardrobe, and even takes you down to the wine cellar for a look at some pretty special bottles.

​

**When to ride: Do this on day 1 of the 7-day plan.**

​

_About: Neal Henderson is one of the most accomplished coaches in cycling and multi-sport. His athletes have won more than 50 World Championships, set numerous world and national records, captured Olympic medals, worn leaders jerseys, and won stages in races like the Tour de France. Neal, a former professional triathlete, has won numerous Coach of the Year awards throughout his career from organizations like the US Olympic Committee, USA Cycling and USA Triathlon. Watch the Introduction to this series to learn more._

prospects.name: UAE Tour 1
prospects.description:
**Featured rider:** Alessandro DEMARCHI of Italy

**Event:** UAE Tour

**Mission - "The Wounded":** An early crash has put a serious dent into your goal of winning the Queen Stage at the UAE Tour. Nevertheless, you've managed to recover and have rejoined the peloton and the GC favorites just at the base of the stage's major climb. Bridging the gap has taken its toll and you'll need to muster all of your strength and courage just to keep going. Can you defy the odds and not just finish with the pack but take the win? Be prepared for a big, long slog up Jebel Jais, the highest point in the UAE.

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: Tempo Build: 1 x 60
prospects.description:
Tempo sessions are always a great time to work on pace control, especially Tempo efforts longer than 30 minutes. We are taking that pacing demand a bit further in this session by forcing you to slightly increase your effort as time goes on. This is referred to as a "Negative-Split", meaning the second half is faster (or you hold a higher power) than the first half.

​

While you might question the benefit of doing "easier" tempo efforts, the truth is when riding between 80% and 100% of FTP your body processes oxygen and metabolites at nearly the same rate. Holding a higher power will give you a higher single day training stimulus, but looking at the big picture that can have its drawbacks. Mainly the fatigue those harder sessions cause, which requires easier workouts the days before and after. Sticking to the Tempo targets gets you nearly the same training stimulus while allowing you to hit harder sessions the rest of the week.

​

This session contains a single 60-minute tempo effort, broken into three 20-minute segments. You will spend the first 20-minutes at 80% of FTP, the next 20 at 84%, and the final 20 at 87%. By the time you hit the last 10-minutes of this effort, that 87% will feel much harder than it should. Another way of thinking about this one, if you were to reverse the order, and start at 87%, what you would likely find is that your RPE stays fairly consistent for the entire effort, even though the power targets are dropping.

​

Overheating, not drinking enough, being under-fueled and mental fatigue will all play a factor in how you feel in that final block. They will also impact your heart rate. While these power targets are usually associated with Zone 3 heart rate, many people will see their heart rate climb into low Z4 if they are not hydrating properly, or have inadequate cooling. This can be a great session to act as a "wake up call" on any poor training habits you might have so take note and aim to address those issues during your next workout.

​

**Warm Up**

30 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: NA

Rest between sets: NA

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

20 minutes @ RPE 6 -- 80% of FTP -- HR <100

20 minutes@ RPE 6.5 -- 84% of FTP -- HR <100%

20 minutes @ RPE 7 -- 87% of FTP -- HR <100%

​

**Extra Volume**

45 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Sprints: 15 x 10s
prospects.description:
This is a session that you'll want to complete in Level, rather than Erg, mode. The only time we would suggest Erg mode is if you are unable to maintain the lower power targets set between sprints.

With short maximal sprint efforts, you'll recruit every muscle fiber you have in your legs each effort. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal force. Just like cadence builds this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system. Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down effect to the longer duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

This session is a great alternate to cadence builds or standing starts for those completing our SUF Strength sessions. On days you complete off the bike strength work you want your on-bike training to complement the suffering you put yourself through off the bike. That means short maximal efforts (whether for power or for cadence) are the best workouts to complement the strength gains you've made off the bike.

As long as you run this session in slope mode you can complete the sprints either seated or out of the saddle. For those competing in events that do not require much (if any) standing (such as Time Trials or Triathlons) you should complete these sprints seated (and in the aero bars or drops if that is where you are racing).

You should also do these efforts seated if you don't feel an out-of-the-saddle maximal sprint is stable/safe to do on your trainer. Regardless of using ERG or Slope mode, you do not want to hold anything back on any sprint. Seeing your peak power drop as the session goes on is totally normal as your legs fatigue. This is where RPE really becomes the most important metric, rather than power, heart rate, or cadence.

Now get on that bike and CRUSH IT!

​

**Warm-Up**

10 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets

1

Rest Between Sets:

N/A

Interval Repeats per Set:

15

**Interval:**

Sprint 10 seconds @ RPE 10 -- MAX SPRINT

**Recovery:**

9 minutes 50 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: MAP Micro Intervals: 3 Sets 40/20s
prospects.description:
For any of you who have completed Blender, Mini Blender, or the Chores, you will be familiar with the 40/20 variety of Pain Shakes that this session serves up

​

40/20s are a go-to workout for Sir Neal Henderson when dishing out pain to the athletes he coaches. While the first few efforts in each set will feel "easy," since these blocks are stretched out to 8-minutes in length, you will be deep into the red by the end of each set.

While the efforts aren't continuous, they are long enough that you will accumulate plenty of time near your VO2max, which is the goal of any MAP workout. The real kicker from this session is how much time you spend at 100% of MAP. Each 8-minute set gives you 5 minutes and 20-seconds of time at your 5-minute peak power. By the end, you are looking at 16 minutes of accumulated MAP efforts, so expect this one to bring some pain!

​

**Warm Up**

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute 15 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

30 seconds @ RPE 4 -- 70% of FTP -- HR <80%

30 seconds @ RPE 8 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 8.5 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105%%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 150% of FTP -- HR >105%

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3

Rest between sets: 5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: 8

​

**Interval**

Work: 40 seconds @ RPE 8.5 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105%

Rest: 20 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

3 minutes 45 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: # Getting Away With It (November Groundwork Challenge)
prospects.description:
This workout is part of the Wahoo X Monthly Challenge. Click [++here++](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/t/wahoo-november-challenge-groundwork/30430) to find out more.

​

Wouldn't it be great if you could leave work to go for a ride? Even for an hour? Well, now's your chance. _Getting Away With It_ gets you out of the office and onto the roads of the French Pyrenees with your guide Michael Cotty of The Col Collective.

​

This is a great session to add toward the end of a training block. The shorter duration, sub-threshold efforts are fantastic for getting some extra FTP building while you are in a fatigued state. Extra emphasis on cadence stresses your nervous system, making your body more efficient at higher and lower RPMs while improving your form. The Neuromuscular training you get from this session is fantastic, so while your power never exceeds threshold, your body will learn to bring more energy to the pedals at all intensities.

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Serenity
prospects.description:
Starting at the islands iconic rainbow rocks at Los Azulejos de Veneguera in this session we tackle one of the most stunning climbs on the whole island, known locally as “Serenity”. We’ll be breaking this 10km climb down into three distinct sections, kicking off with a block of 6 x 50 second high tempo efforts with a 10 second burst out of the saddle before taking a swift breather before getting back on it. As we climb through the pine forest we’ll switch things up a touch, alternating between low and high cadence for 30 seconds at a time for around 7 minutes. We’ll then revert back to our 50 second high tempo with 10 second burst out of the saddle efforts before we build up our effort to the summit. This is going to be a challenging workout so make sure you’re ready and whatever you do don’t forget to take a moment to look at the views!!

​

This workout combines multiple different interval types that focus on improving threshold power via over-under style efforts along with low cadence work for your muscular endurance. The first and last climbs also fire up your whole energy systems with some sprints to the summit.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8735613403)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: MAP: 2 Sets 8 x 1
prospects.description:
The goal of this session is to accumulate a significant amount of time near your VO2max, or the point at which your body is consuming as much oxygen as it possibly can. That means your heart rate and breathing rate will both be near their max by the end of each interval, especially in the final few intervals.

​

Since it takes time for your heart rate and breathing rate to match your effort, for the first part of each interval, you will be tapping into your Anaerobic Capacity to produce the required power. To account for this, we have limited the recovery duration to be equal to the interval duration. Limited recovery ensures that you will drain your Anaerobic Capacity before the end of the intervals, meaning your body will be forced to produce as much power as possible using oxygen.

​

**Warm-Up**

15 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- 90%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-180% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: 2 hours @ RPE 4 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 8

**Interval **

Effort: 1 minutes @ RPE 9 -- 90-110% of MAP (115-135% of FTP)

Recovery: 1 minutes @ RPE 2 -- <45% of FTP

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Last Rider
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2022): The heroic true story of American cyclist Greg LeMond, considered to be one of the greatest cyclists of all time, who defied the odds for one of the most triumphant comeback stories in sporting history. The first, male American to win the Tour de France, LeMond came back from the brink of death to beat his famed rivals in the historic and nail-biting race at the 1989 Tour de France.

Directed by Alex Holmes and featuring exclusive interviews with LeMond and his wife Kathy as well as, never before seen footage, The Last Rider is an exhilarating portrait of one of the greatest athletes of our time.

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of Cav's lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Adventure For All 2023
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): As one of Wahoo's close partners, Adventure For All's mission is to guide individuals with exceptionalities through life-changing adventures while creating innovative educational practices that ignite a shift in societal belief systems.Together we will guide individuals with exceptionalities through life-changing adventures while creating innovative educational practices that ignite a shift in societal belief systems.

​

**Experience the Adirondacks:**

Join four exceptional athletes in the Adirondack mountains on the adventure of a lifetime. These athletes challenge themselves, conquer fears, and demonstrate their ability to overcome obstacles, proving to themselves and the world they can achieve anything.

​

**Finish:**

Witness Riley, a remarkable young man with Autism and Tourette's, as he pedals beyond expectations to conquer the challenging 31+ mile Big Sugar gravel bike race. This isn't just a story about cycling; it's a journey of courage, hope, and the shattering barriers. With the unwavering support of his mom and the dedicated team at Adventure For All, Riley's adventure redefines what's possible, turning every pedal stroke into a victory for him and everyone who believed in his endless potential.

​

[**Find out more about Adventure For All**](https://adventureforall.org/)

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Open: 40
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head out to make room for more serious sessions. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session is from the Road Race of The Hammer Series.

prospects.name: Heart Flatline to Finish Line
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2021): Heart Flatline to Finish Line is the raw and emotional journey of six cardiac patients from hospital beds to the finish line of one of the world's most grueling endurance events, the Ironman triathlon.

​

🚴Workout: This workout is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP; mostly endurance with a sprinkling of low tempo mixed in. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: The Laps Tasmania
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2019): Following Dustin Hollick and Rhian Slapp, two ordinary fathers with the survival skills of well-trained house pets, on a two-week journey around Tasmania with not much more than the clothes on their backs. No cash, no car, and no technology on an island at the bottom of the world.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: AC: 6 x 45s
prospects.description:
There's no getting around the fact that this is a profoundly unpleasant session that will leave your legs feeling like jelly. This session is similar to The Trick, with a few differences. On the plus side, all of the efforts are 15-seconds shorter than those in The Trick. To make up for this, we added two more intervals to this session, bringing the total to 6. That means by the end of this session you will have plowed through 4.5-minutes of AC work.

This workout is one of the few sessions that we do NOT recommend you complete in ERG mode if you are on a smart trainer. The goal is to hold onto the highest power you can for the full 45-seconds. Inevitably in the later sets, your power will dip before you reach the end of the interval. What we want is for you to complete every effort having given everything for 45-seconds. We don't want ERG mode grinding you to a halt because you cannot maintain the (ridiculously) high power targets. Even if you drop down below FTP in the final 10-seconds of these efforts, as long as you are going flat out, you are doing it correctly.

Just take this session one interval at a time, and focus on giving your all for this one effort. You can worry about the others when you get to them. If you finish this session without swearing, then you didn't go hard enough!

​

**Warm Up**

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

1 minute 15 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <70

30 seconds @ RPE 4 -- 70% of FTP -- HR <70

45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <90

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

15 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105

45 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

15 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 200% of FTP -- HR >105

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 6

Rest Between Sets: 5 minutes 15 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70

Interval Repeats Per Set: N/A

**Interval**

Effort: 45 seconds @ RPE 9.5 -- 150% of FTP -- HR >105

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

4 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70

prospects.name: Wolfpack Insider: France
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): Deceuninck –This documentary chronicles the journey of Deceuninck–Quick-Step during the 2019 Tour de France. Go behind the scenes with one of the world's most successful PRO teams as they navigate the ups and downs of cycling's biggest race.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Tour of Norway 2
prospects.description:
**Featured rider:** Carl Fredrick HAGEN of Norway

**Event: **Tour of Norway

**Mission - "Wonderkid":** Experience the thrill of the breakaway with the peloton breathing down your neck - You're riding for Team Lotto Soudal - You've been in the breakaway all day. There's just one hour of racing left and you're sitting at the top of the virtual GC on the last day of the Tour of Norway, your home tour — Of any day to go all out and empty the tank, today is the day — Take your pulls, lead the breakaway and fight to stay away from the peloton.

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: Tempo Increasing: 20/16/8/4min
prospects.description:
In this workout, the shorter the interval duration, the higher the power target will be. Starting from 20 minutes of low Tempo, and finishing with 4-minutes of high-quality MAP work, proper pacing is crucial to success in this workout. While you could easily be above target power for the entire 20-minute effort, that would set you up to fail in the last two efforts. Be smart and pace yourself; you can always go harder in the final 5-minute effort if you want to!


At any intensity above Endurance pace, the longer you ride, the more fatigued you become. Completing the final 5-minute target when fresh would be unpleasant, hitting it after all of these other intervals makes it a near maximal effort. Proper hydration/cooling and nutrition are vital if you want to nail this workout.


If you are preparing for any longer ride/event where you will be required to keep on the gas from start to finish, this is the perfect session for you. Completing these efforts in this order not only gives a great physical training boost but also toughens you up mentally. Digging deep when fatigued is the key to good performance over longer distances, so expect to suffer in that final 5-minute effort; it will pay off both mentally and physically!

​

**Warm Up **

30 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 4, all unique

Rest Between Sets: 12 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

Interval Repeats per Set: N/A

**Set 1** (20-minute Effort)

Steady: 20 minutes @ RPE 7 -- 85% of FTP-- HR <95%

**Set 2** x4(16-minute Effort) 

Steady: 3 minutes @ RPE 7.25 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

Surge: 1 minute @ RPE 7.75 -- 105% of FTP-- HR <105%

**Set 3 **(8-minute Effort)

Surge: 1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 90% of MAP (105-125% of FTP)

Steady: 6 minutes @ RPE 7.25 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

Surge: 1 minute @ RPE 9 -- 95% of MAP (110-135% of FTP)

**Set 4 **(4-minute Effort)

Effort 1: 1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 90% of MAP (105-125% of FTP)

Effort 2: 1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP

Effort 3: 1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 90% of MAP (105-125% of FTP)

Effort 4: 1 minute @ RPE 9.5 -- 100+% of MAP (120-150% of FTP)

​

**Extra Volume **

55 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <85%

​

**Cool Down **

6 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- <45% of FTP -- HR <70

prospects.name: Catalunya: Costa Brava Coastline
prospects.description:
Today we’re going to be riding one of the most incredible roads of Spain's Catalan region, going from St Feliu de Guíxols over to Tossa de Mar and hugging the Costa Brava coastline the whole way. Continually undulating we’ll hit each of the eight rolling climbs hard, working at low cadence with high intensity to build strength. Mike will keep you focused on good form, though, and make sure you keep the power down on all the way over each summit.

​

It wouldn't be an On Location ride, though, if we didn't have a look at the scenic attractions along the way, though, so get ready for craggy rocks, turquoise clear waters, and a few opportunities to delve into the Costa Brava’s finest as we find out more about the region along this 21km route.

​

[Route on Strava](https://www.strava.com/routes/2967787441439728434)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: The Chores
prospects.description:
If you want a do-it-all session that will maintain and improve nearly every aspect of your fitness, _The Chores_ is just the ticket. This workout features 3 sets of intervals. Each set combines a series of 40-second efforts with 20-second recoveries, followed by an immediate transition to a sustained effort just below threshold. These short efforts with minimal recovery deplete your anaerobic gas tank, forcing your body to get better at producing power aerobically. This combination will help improve your Anaerobic Capacity, (AC) your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and your Functional Threshold Power (FTP), all in just under an hour.

​

At the start of each set, your body starts to dip into your anaerobic reserves to help hit the high-power targets. Your body then starts to ramp up your oxygen intake in order to produce more of the power requirements aerobically. With such short recovery time between these efforts, your AC is steadily drained through each set. By the time the last short interval arrives, your body will be forced to produce almost all of that power aerobically, which will push your lungs to their very limit.

​

This is the optimal time to stress your body’s ability to produce power at threshold. With your AC depleted (and your lungs and heart working near maximal capacity), the shorter sustained efforts that would normally be a piece of cake will have a bit more...sting. No matter what your preferred discipline, terrain, or distance, this session will make you fitter and faster.

​

Featuring exciting, on-bike camera footage from the Velon Hammer Series, _The Chores_ will make you earn your keep.

prospects.name: Tempo Alternating: 1 x 20
prospects.description:
This short, 36-minute workout will get you in and out of Sufferlandria in no time, with a solid 20 minute tempo block to boot. This continuous tempo effort will have you alternate between 75 & 85% of FTP every minute. Not only does this help pass the time rather quickly, it will help improve your aerobic fitness. Time spent in this intensity range will help increase your stroke volume (amount of blood your heart can pump every minute), your lactate threshold, and the mitochondrial density of your muscles (mitochondria are the "power houses" of the cells that create energy). All of these things are very important parts of aerobic metabolism and performing your best- especially if you like group rides. This is the typical intensity range that most group rides fall into- not a leisurely pace, but not so fast that people are falling off the back within minutes. So if you find that you commonly struggle with group rides, gradually spending more time on workouts at this intensity will have you holding on longer and taking your pulls without missing a beat!

​

**Warm Up**

6 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 10

Rest between sets: NA

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

Work: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <100

Steady: 1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Found in America
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): After finishing the Race Across America on the podium, Dave Haase is coming back to win it. But is that what he's really looking for? Is there more to why he's taking on such a formidable challenge than the pursuit of victory alone? This is an honest look at the demands of a legendary ultra-endurance race and what one finds out on the road.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: MAP: 3 x 2
prospects.description:
The goal of this session is to accumulate a significant amount of time near your VO2max, or the point at which your body is consuming as much oxygen as it possibly can. That means your heart rate and breathing rate will both be near their max by the end of each interval, especially in the final few intervals.

​

Since it takes time for your heart rate and breathing rate to match your effort, for the first part of each interval, you will be tapping into your Anaerobic Capacity to produce the required power. To account for this, we have limited the recovery duration to be equal to the interval duration. Limited recovery ensures that you will drain your Anaerobic Capacity before the end of the intervals, meaning your body will be forced to produce as much power as possible using oxygen.

​

**Warm Up**

10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <65%

7 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%

2 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <85%

3 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-180% of FTP)

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: N/A

Interval Repeats Per Set: 3

**Interval**

Effort: 2 minutes @ RPE 9 -- 95-105% of MAP (115-135% of FTP)

Recovery: 6 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

8 minutes @ RPE 1 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Endurance  2
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

Warm-Up

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

Main Effort

Number of Sets

5

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set

1

Interval: 10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

Extra Volume

N/A

​

Cool Down

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: 02. Identifying Your Personal Big Mountain
prospects.description:
What - exactly - are you trying to accomplish? When you're ready to answer that question, this module will help you gain clarity on who you are as an athlete and identify your major goal—your Personal Big Mountain.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Importance of SMART Goal Setting](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/start-now-goal-setting-basics)' and '[How to use your personal outlook to set more effective goals](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/know-thyself-how-to-use-your-personal-outlook-to-set-more-effective-goals)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: 07. Positive Self-Talk
prospects.description:
Improve your confidence and performance through three types of positive self-talk: Motivational, Instructional, and Reward. Here, we’ll look at the subtle and not-so-subtle effects that words have on our attitude and performance. You’ll listen more closely to the way you talk to yourself so you can improve that internal dialogue and become your own biggest fan.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Power of Positive Mental Strategies](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/episode-29-how-to-use-positive-self-talk-to-get-through-tough-moments-on-a-ride-mental-strategies)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Fitness.

prospects.name: 06. Relaxing to Recover
prospects.description:
Here you will complete a full Progressive Muscle Relaxation session. It’s part guided meditation and part focus exercise. You should listen to this module at least once per week to get in tune with your body, release tension, and maximize recovery.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 08. Improving Focus
prospects.description:
Develop an understanding of why focused concentration is so important to your performance. We will delve into what it means to be in “The Zone," look at the psychology and the physiology of peak performance, and what it takes to get there.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 04. Getting Positive
prospects.description:
Thoughts matter. To accomplish big goals you need the ability to maintain a positive mindset, regardless of what life gives you. Here's an overview of the power of maintaining a positive mindset. We’ll introduce specific techniques that will help you identify negative thoughts, see obstacles as opportunities, and take a more positive path forward.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 20. Preparing To Crush It
prospects.description:
This pre-event visualization exercise will help you get in the zone to deliver what athletes and sports psychologists call a “peak performance;” it’s when everything flows and operates at the highest level almost without any effort.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 21. How Did it Go?
prospects.description:
Once the dust has settled and your heart rate has returned to normal levels, listen to this module. It's meant to be completed 15 minutes after the event ends. Part two of this exercise is completed the next day when you’ve had time to process and reflect on everything that happened during the event day.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: Total Newbie Yoga
prospects.description: Yoga-curious but don't know where to start? This session is a great place to dip your toes in. This easy, basic routine will introduce you to some simple foundational moves while giving you a little stretch and some light strength work at the same time. Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Chest & Shoulder Strength
prospects.description:
This yoga sequence is designed to strengthen the upper body, targeting the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core. It's an ideal routine to practice in the morning or before a workout to activate muscles throughout the body. The intensity can be increased by lifting the knees during push-ups, providing a challenge to work towards.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Triceps Push-Ups
- Plank
- Child
- Downward Dog
- Puppy
- Chest Stretch
- Triceps Stretch
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Breathing to Crush Them
prospects.description: This is the breathing technique used by Navy Seals to help them focus and find calm before major operations. Learn and use this technique before heading into your own major events and races.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Mobilize and Activate
prospects.description: Get out of your habitual movement patterns and get ready to take on the day with this activation session. You'll flow through a series of standing yoga poses to simultaneously challenge your strength, flexibility, and range of motion, leaving you feeling energized.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Side Bends
prospects.description: If you're pushing yourself hard, it's likely you're getting stiff and sore all over. Side bends are one of my favorite ways to deal with general soreness. They're also perfect for cyclists who typically suffer from poor lateral flexibility.

prospects.name: Upper Body Strength
prospects.description: Those things you use to type and lift up your coffee cup? Yeah, those could be a bit stronger. So it's time to build strength in your upper body—in the hands, wrists, arms, shoulders, chest, and core. It is based around Sun Salutation, a yoga sequence that builds strength, increases power, and improves endurance.

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Full Body Mobility
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve the range of motion throughout the body, focusing on the spine, shoulders, and hips. It combines twists, side bends, and balance poses to enhance total body flexibility and agility.

prospects.name: Yoga for Travel
prospects.description: If you're traveling and will be off your bike for some time, you might feel that all is lost. But we've created a routine for travelers to keep you balanced, loose, and strong. Do this daily while on the road so you'll be in top condition when you can get back home.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Core Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the spine, ribs and pelvis; strengthen the deep abdominals, obliques and lower back; and activate the glutes to improve balance, help to prevent and alleviate lower back pain and enhance athletic performance. It's a great session to do in the morning or pre-workout.

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Hip and Pelvis Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we strengthen the hips through their full range of motion and stabilize the pelvis to improve balance and reduce your risk of knee, IT band, and lower back injury. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners II
prospects.description: Building on the gains you've achieved after doing the Core Strengtheners exercises several times, this session further strengthens the core.

prospects.name: Lower Back Release
prospects.description:
This video is designed to alleviate tightness in the lower back by releasing tension in the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of reclining hip-opening poses combined with deep, diaphragmatic breathing.

​

The objectives are to stretch the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves, improve mobility in the hips and spine, and help alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Wind-Relieving
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Dead Pigeon
- Happy Baby

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Balance and Agility
prospects.description: Maintaining effective cycling form when you're under pressure requires substantial balance, coordination, agility, and core strength. This series will develop those capabilities so you can put down the power when it really matters.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Full Body Mobility
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve the range of motion throughout the body, focusing on the spine, shoulders, and hips. It combines twists, side bends, and balance poses to enhance total body flexibility and agility.

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Peak Pose Wheel
prospects.description:
This sequence builds towards the advanced backbend, Wheel pose. To prepare for this pose, the routine focuses on mobilizing the spine and shoulders and opening up the fronts of the hips. It is best practiced when fully warmed up, with careful attention to the lower back and only moving within safe ranges of motion. For those who can practice Wheel safely, it serves as an excellent counterpose to common postures from cycling or sitting at a desk, potentially alleviating lower back, upper back, and shoulder pain. For those not yet ready for Wheel, the other poses in this sequence are also effective for addressing muscular imbalances.

​

The objectives are to increase spinal and shoulder mobility, stretch the abs, chest, and fronts of the shoulders, open up the hip flexors, activate the glutes, and help alleviate lower and upper back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Supported Bridge
- Thunderbolt—Shoulder Rolls
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Puppy
- Downward Facing Dog
- Cobra
- Low Lunge with Shoulder Opener
- Bridge
- Wheel
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Chest & Shoulder Strength
prospects.description:
This yoga sequence is designed to strengthen the upper body, targeting the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core. It's an ideal routine to practice in the morning or before a workout to activate muscles throughout the body. The intensity can be increased by lifting the knees during push-ups, providing a challenge to work towards.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Triceps Push-Ups
- Plank
- Child
- Downward Dog
- Puppy
- Chest Stretch
- Triceps Stretch
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Mobilize and Activate
prospects.description: Get out of your habitual movement patterns and get ready to take on the day with this activation session. You'll flow through a series of standing yoga poses to simultaneously challenge your strength, flexibility, and range of motion, leaving you feeling energized.

prospects.name: Yoga for Travel
prospects.description: If you're traveling and will be off your bike for some time, you might feel that all is lost. But we've created a routine for travelers to keep you balanced, loose, and strong. Do this daily while on the road so you'll be in top condition when you can get back home.

prospects.name: Side Bends
prospects.description: If you're pushing yourself hard, it's likely you're getting stiff and sore all over. Side bends are one of my favorite ways to deal with general soreness. They're also perfect for cyclists who typically suffer from poor lateral flexibility.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Pre-Ride Warm-Up
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to activate your posterior chain—the calves, hamstrings, glutes, lower, upper, and mid-back, as well as your core—the abs and obliques. It’s crucial that you engage these muscles before every ride to give you maximum power, speed, and endurance on the bike.

​

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Core Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the spine, ribs and pelvis; strengthen the deep abdominals, obliques and lower back; and activate the glutes to improve balance, help to prevent and alleviate lower back pain and enhance athletic performance. It's a great session to do in the morning or pre-workout.

prospects.name: Hips and Hamstrings
prospects.description: This routine is designed to open up the hips—the hip flexors, rotators, and glutes—and stretch the hamstrings. The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.name: Foot & Ankle Recovery
prospects.description:
In this restorative sequence, the focus is on mobilizing the toes, feet, and ankles, stretching the calves and hamstrings, and opening up the hips. The session begins with a calming breathing technique, followed by a simple foot massage to introduce movement from the toes up to the heel. With increased range of motion, the routine progresses to gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips. Since feet are often neglected and subjected to high demands from activities like running or cycling, practicing this sequence at least once a week helps to rebalance and address this issue.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the feet and ankles, stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Easy Seat
- Box Breathing
- Foot Massage
- Downward Dog
- Screaming Toe
- Yoga Squat
- Ankle Stretch
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Hips and Hamstrings
prospects.description: This routine is designed to open up the hips—the hip flexors, rotators, and glutes—and stretch the hamstrings. The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.
